ygData.subject: Re: Alternative fitness sharing method
ygData.msgSnippet: Hey Colin, Your alternative fitness sharing method is a really interesting idea, and our thinking may be going in similar directions because of our recent

Subject: Re: Alternative fitness sharing method
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=130984297; y=A71dR6pokDi-L-maHqkrxdrT_l1RusmLOP3NJHynSRM7tWD6LPYw
X-Yahoo-Profile: joel278

Hey Colin,

Your alternative fitness sharing method is a really interesting=
 idea, and our thinking may be going in similar directions because of our r=
ecent discussions. Have you had a chance to read Ken and I's recent publica=
tion on novelty search and local competition: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publi=
cations/2011/lehman.gecco11.html? Some of
the ideas we introduce there are =
somewhat similar in spirit to what you are suggesting.

In that publication=
 we apply NS to evolve virtual creatures. We look
both for creatures with n=
ovel morphologies and those that have high
fitness relative to their morpho=
logical niche. 

That is, we have a space of morphologies characterized by =
height and
weight. Within that 2D space we reward both novelty and localize=
d fitness (fitness normalized by looking at its kNN in the 2D morphology sp=
ace, this type of normalization might also work in your instance). These tw=
o objectives are balanced using a multi-objective evolutionary algorithm. T=
he end result is that you an discover a wide diversity of different functio=
nal morphologies within a single run.

Another way of looking at our approa=
ch is that we are implicitly doing
fitness sharing in a derived 2D space to=
 encourage local specialization within niches -- that is, a tall, skinny cr=
eature does
not compete directly with a medium-sized, medium-weight morphol=
ogy
that may be more naturally suited to fast locomotion. This seems somewh=
at related to your idea, although yours involves additional evaluations and=
 weighted averages of different fitnesses depending on the X,Y niching coor=
dinates.

Your suggestion of a more general conception of incremental evolu=
tion
is interesting as well. One problem with incremental evolution
is that=
 you have to know both what the stepping stones are and the order in which =
they should be discovered to create some sort of training plan. Your genera=
lization might alleviate the need to know the "order" of the stepping stone=
s because genomes can specialize to whatever objective they are most suited=
 to (by changing their XY through mutation).

Anyways, I look forward to se=
eing your idea further developed, it seems like a cool approach to potentia=
lly evolve more complex things.

Joel

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin"=
 <colin.green1@...> wrote:
>
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <co=
lin.green1@> wrote:
> 
> > Typically the x,y here could be weightings given=
 to different aspects
> > of a fitness function or we could combine two dis=
tinct fitness
> > functions with weights (which amounts to the same thing).=
 So e.g.
> > 
> >    f(G, x, y) =3D (f1(G) * x) + (f2(G) * y)
> 
> On relfe=
ction this isn't quite right. One weigting would adjust the balance between=
 two fitness functions, e.g.
> 
>     f(G, x) =3D (f1(G) * x) + (f2(G) * (1=
-x))
> 
> So for a 2D space you'd have something like:
> 
>     f(G, x, y) =
=3D (f1(G) * x) + (f2(G) * (1-x)) 
>                + (f3(G) * y) + (f4(G) =
* (1-y)) 
> 
> 
> We also need a way to make selection not become biased to=
wards Individuals in one part of the space because they get better fitness =
there - maybe the fitnesses need be normalized in some way (max in each reg=
ion is the same) but that doesn't feel quite right (needs more thought).
> =

> I'll also give an example of a domain to try and explain why this might =
work. Consider a fitness function with just 1 dimension f(G,x) and we're tr=
yign to evolve a bipedal walker. f1 could be a standing still test (not fal=
ling over), f2 could be the walking distance test. So you're genomes start =
out by doing well on f1 and then some migrate over to f2 to populate that r=
egion of the fitness space. It does mean more CPU effort having to evaulate=
 f1 and f2, and you also need to define network inputs such that you can te=
ll the biped whether to stand or walk, so it's not an entirely trivial swap=
 in replacement of G based fitness sharing, but I'm warming to the idea the=
 more I think about it.
> 
> Colin.
>
